Award.AwardTitle: Research Experiences for Undergraduate Site: Multi-physics of Active Systems and Structures

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
The three year REU Site program will enhance the educational experience of undergraduate engineering students by actively engaging them in advanced research activities within FAMU-FSU College of Engineering (CoE). The newly constructed Aeropropulsion, Mechatronics and Energy (AME) Research Building will provide an excellent setting for the program. First, the REU Site program will be a collective effort with the participation of a diverse group of engineering faculty. A wide range of advanced topics are proposed including the development of micro air vehicles, multi-modal robots, active flow control, sensors and actuators, smart materials, energy harvesting and storage, etc.. The multidisciplinary nature of these projects will engage students in cross-cutting technologies by inspiring the integration and synthesis of ideas and facilitating a better understanding of engineering design at the system level. During the summer, the student researchers will also participate in several innovative programs aimed at enriching their experience, including a Learning Through Teaching program and an engineering design competition to promote teamwork and collaborative design activities.

The CoE is the only Ph.D. granting engineering college in the nation that combines the strengths of an HBCU (Historically Black College and University) in Florida A & M University and a major research university in FSU. The Mechanical Engineering Department has a number of faculty with established track records in both scholarly activities and recruitment and education of minority and female engineering students. Thus, the REU site program will have broader impacts by increasing the number of US engineering students, in particular underrepresented minorities and women, who will pursue advanced degrees. Results will be disseminated at educational conferences, in journal articles, and by conducting workshops and distributing newsletters. This information will also be made available through a dedicated website.

"This site is co-funded by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program."

ProgramReference.Text: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of the program is to motivate more US students to pursue advanced engineering degrees or enter research-oriented careers.  To achieve this goal, we have engaged undergraduate engineering students for an educational and professional enhancement program that involved them in advanced research activities and group design experience. 

 

We have recruited 49 students during the past four summers (2012-2015) through a competitive selection process based on demographics, academic qualifications and interests that are matched to existing research projects.  These students worked on individualized projects and participate in group activities such as seminars, lab/industry tours, outreach, and group design project.  Working with colleagues from the College of Education, we have assessed the effectiveness of the program by systematically conducting surveys, interviews, and project reviews.    

 

Intellectual merits: The site has been a collective effort from a diverse group of 12 engineering faculty who specialize in topics such as micro air vehicles, robots, supersonic flow, active flow control, autonomous control, sensors and actuators, smart materials, etc.. The multidisciplinary nature of these projects has engaged students in learning cross-cutting technologies through their specific research and group activities.  We have devised group design projects with multiple components that incorporate participants’ individual research topics, knowledge and skill sets.  The group projects were organized to facilitate a better understanding of engineering design at the system level while promoting teamwork and collaborative design activities.  We have also involved all participants in planned activities to promote self-reflection to achieve specific understanding of their experiences leading to a deeper learning.

 

Broader Impacts: The FAMU-FSU College of Engineering, while combining the strengths of an HBCU in Florida A&M University and a major research university in Florida State University, has many faculty members with established track records in both scholarly activities and recruitment and education of minority and female engineering students.  Our REU site has worked successfully in the REU program to increase the number of engineering students, in particular under-represented minorities and women, who have pursued advanced degrees. 

 

Overall, 40% REU fellows are under-represented minorities (URM).  Among them, 12% were African American, 12% Hispanic American, and 32% females. These numbers are higher than the general demographic distribution percentages of these URM groups in mechanical engineering, which are 4%, 9%, and 13.5%, respectively according to American Society of Engineering Education database.   All REU alumni have been very successful in pursuing their careers after graduation.  Among those who had graduated, 39%, have chosen to enter the workforce although a few indicated they would pursue graduate degrees in a few years.  They were hired by engineering companies such as Northrup Grumman, Boeing, Exxon Mobile, Harris, etc.  About 55% of them continued advanced degrees and 42% started pursuing their PhD degrees in various schools such as Florida State University, Georgia Tech, U. Colorado, UCLA, Vanderbilt, Texas A&M, Missouri Science & Technology, Kentucky, UC Riverside, Carnegie Mellon, and Notre Dame.
